title: Will Haiti hold a presidential election before 1 January 2022?
preds:
Comments: See cabinet formation by Henry ineffective. Affirming forecast. 
Relief Web, 11/24/21, 'Thousands stranded and exposed as insecurity worsens in Port-au-Prince': https://reliefweb.int/report/haiti/thousands-stranded-and-exposed-insecurity-worsens-port-au-prince
As of 19 Nov, political instability is non-supportive of an effective election.

Comments: Affirming forecast due to the continued power vacuum and instability.
NPR, 11/01/21, 'Fuel shortages are bringing Haiti to a halt': https://www.npr.org/2021/11/01/1051215645/fuel-shortages-are-bringing-haiti-to-a-halt
Clip from article:
'Gangs are blocking fuel shipments - gangs that have become increasingly powerful in Haiti, filling the power vacuum created by all that recent turmoil. Everything from hospitals to cellphone towers are running out of gas.'
Miami Herald, 10/31/21, 'Human-rights activists accuse new Haiti police chief of past repression and abuse': https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/haiti/article255199321.html

Recent interview with the prime minister lays out a time and there appears to be a lot to accomplish between now and a new president – new constitution and establishing a new electoral board. PM Ariel Henry’s timeline is to try to have these elections conducted in the second half of 2022 so there will be a new elected president by the end of 2022. “Elections are the other priority. My job is to be out of a job, by having an elected president take office as soon as possible. To that end, we will first establish a new, inclusive electoral board (CEP) to ensure free and fair elections. Once we have a new electoral board, it will be up to the board to put forward as soon as possible an electoral calendar so we may elect a president and parliament and conduct local elections, which are so long overdue. It is my objective to have these elections conducted in the second half of 2022, so that we may have an elected president before the end of 2022.” https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2021/10/11/haiti-elections-constitution-ariel-henry-moise-vision-unity/

Comments: Affirming forecast.
UN News, 10/04/21, 'Haiti facing stalled elections, kidnapping surge, rampant insecurity': https://news.un.org/en/story/2021/10/1102062
Clip from article:
'In a positive step towards reviving democratic institutions, politicians from across the spectrum, including former opposition and ruling coalition groups, reached an agreement on 11 September, to form a new Provisional Electoral Council, with a view to holding elections no later than the second half of 2022.'

I would say there is really no chance that Haiti will hold a presidential election by the deadline of this question of 1 January 2022. A deadline one year later would certainly be higher but there is simply insufficient time for Haiti to organize and hold elections by the beginning of 2022, less than 3 months away. Most notably, Haiti's Prime Minister, Ariel Henry, publicly stated that he plans to modify the Haiti constitution by February and then hold elections sometime early in the year after that. (https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/haiti-pm-elections-referendum-held-year-80289104) There have been several postponements of the elections following the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in July 2021. Even the Prime Minister's statements are being challenged as unlawful with accusations he is attempting to hold on to power in Haiti illegally. (https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/haiti-pm-elections-referendum-held-year-80289104)
I guess that's a firm no now

https://apnews.com/article/elections-caribbean-port-au-prince-haiti-constitutions-f8ca54a40c53bd21057f34952b9508ed
The official word is No, barring a change in government there.
As per a gentle nudge from @bh4eh

Would this delay have occurred in spite of the earthquake? Hard to say. In spite of assassination? Hard to say. But both definitely working in tandem makes this very hard for Haiti to get back up soon. As you know, the PM has said "early next year" now. Small chance it develops sooner but I don't think it's rational.

Comments: See also @bh4eh latest post. Situation still unclear. Affirming forecast.
AP, 09/28/21, 'The AP Interview: Haiti PM plans to hold elections next year': https://www.yourbasin.com/news/haiti-pm-elections-referendum-to-be-held-next-year/
Lowering some for now. Possible "power struggle": https://www.npr.org/2021/09/14/1037012177/haiti-prosecutor-asks-judge-charge-prime-minister-moise-assassination
Sounds like a mess. Moving to the crowd. https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/haiti-faces-fresh-instability-pm-scrutiny-80039222

Comments: Key phrase: 'who knew what and when did they know it'. Foot-dragging continues by principals in investigation. 
Key phrase: 'non-existent state'. No confidence; Haitians voting with their feet. Affirming current forecast.
Al-Jazeera, 09/11/21, 'Haiti PM rejects ‘diversionary tactics’ in Moise killing probe': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/9/11/haiti-pm-rejects-diversionary-tactics-in-moise-killing-probe
Insight Crime, 09/10/21, 'Haiti’s Neighbors Grow Concerned at Spread of Gang Governance': https://insightcrime.org/news/haitis-neighbors-grow-concerned-spread-gang-governance/
Clips from Insight article:
'At the moment, neither the G9 alliance nor smaller, localized gangs have a clear means of force projection abroad, especially in such a complex criminal landscape as the Dominican Republic.
But, second, rising violence is fuelling the exodus of Haitian migrants across the region. Between January and July 2021, Panama registered more than 20,000 Haitians crossing the border, with more each month, up significantly from 2020 when numbers dropped due to the pandemic. Similar crises are taking place with thousands of Haitian migrants stuck in Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Mexico. Gang violence has directly contributed to the numbers of displaced people as well as other criminal economies, including child trafficking from Haiti to the Dominican Republic.
“In Haiti, more than a failing state we have a non-existent state,” economist Joseph Harold Pierre told Bloomberg. But the gangs are all too happy to exist in its place.'

Es bastante probable que Haití tenga elecciones presidenciales dado el actual sistema de crisis, las tensiones internacionales aumentarán dado que la mayoría de latino américa comenzará nuevos períodos de gobiernos, se exigirá a los países que tomen postura frente a esta nueva tendencia de izquierda.
Points dropping on review of state of Haiti - gang violence and sluggish recoveries.
Updating out of respect to crowd median.
Earthquake has made this near impossible

Comments: Affirming forecast.
Yahoo News, 08/30/21, 'His Name Is Barbecue—and He’s Ready to Plunge Haiti Into War': https://news.yahoo.com/name-barbecue-ready-plunge-haiti-084728617.html
Clip from article:
'But the timing of Barbecue’s rise might work to his advantage: The situation in Haiti is now so dire that entire neighborhoods in Port-au-Prince, like Aviation, Delmas, or Martissant, just to name a few, have fallen under complete gang control. Shops, banks, and homes in entire neighborhoods have now been deserted. Gangs essentially control all western entrances by road to the capital. This strategic positioning is not a coincidence; it’s meant to show the government who’s really in charge now. Recent Haitian governments have tried to clear the entrances by sending in special police units, but to no avail.
Friday's presser was the prefect opportunity to delay the election, I'm inclined to believe that if anyone interested in gabbing power will be looking to do so through November's election.

8/22/21 NYT article excerpt: "...Mr. Moïse’s death plunged Haiti into a power vacuum, leaving it without a president, a functioning Parliament or a Supreme Court. Although general elections are officially scheduled for Nov. 7, the caretaker prime minister, Ariel Henry, says the country first needs to tackle pervasive gang violence and appoint a new electoral board." (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/22/world/americas/haiti-earthquake-aid.html) Also, the noted stipulation for this question:  "If a second round must be held to determine a winner and the second round is not held before 1 January 2022, then the question would close "no.""

Although I remain moderate, check out what @chiarapallanch said: "The electoral calendar is called into question by the current relief efforts following the earthquake in mid- August. This is refocusing the political efforts on responding to the disaster."

Back up because there's no news about postponing it again, and there seems to still be some confidence among leader(s) that they can pull it off. I also saw a NYT article saying that candidates are asking for donations or something like that even in the midst of a disaster. So there seems to be political activity in spite. Otherwise, I'd be around 20–35% confident and be near the crowd median. Probabilistic summary: Slightly unlikely.
The electoral calendar is called into question by the current relief efforts following the earthquake in mid- August.  This is refocusing the political efforts on responding to the disaster.
Back up because of leader's promise even in spite of disaster. ntscc

Think I was too low
Also: https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article253553829.html

Misread question. IF there is a second round, they say. So that means more uncertain or should I say less likely. My understanding now is that if the first round occurs with a majority win, this counts. If not, it relies on whether it meets the question deadline. I would say the election chances by 2022 are 50/50 if not more favored to NO. Times the probability of winning a majority the first time? Result is perhaps half of 75-ish.

Haiti Premier Henry reportedly now expects an election delay: "We do not have an election calendar.” https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/as-haiti-reels-from-earthquake-and-deals-with-discord-leader-expects-election-delay/
The aftermath of the earthquake followed by storm Grace does not bode well for the government to adhere to the Nov 7th election date, just 11 weeks away; https://reut.rs/3k2pAn1

A major earthquake, 1,300 people killed, hospitals overrun, a state of emergency for at least one month and another storm heading to Haiti. A real probability that the 7 November election will be delayed. As per today's clarification, (thanks to @timothy_chan - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1320961 for getting the clarification) assuming there's no clear winner in a delayed first round, assuming it takes place before 1 January 2022, the probability of this resolving to 'Yes' continues to diminish IMO. @MCowley

Now is an opportune time to seek political advantage. And if there is a disaster, it will take months to years to recover from it. If recovery not now, 1 year from now, then when? With no new president in the meantime? In some ways, people are still recovering from the 2010 earthquake but there have been subsequent elections, as soon as 10 months after the 2010 devastating one. Haiti has suffered from hurricanes yet carried out its elective process. On the other hand, roads and delivery systems may affect the timeliness of an election, among other reasons.
Dropping a few more points on news of Tropical Cyclone Grace moving through.  Will be looking to revise position again after the cyclone has passed.

An early report, excerpt: 
"...Saturday's quake was far less damaging than the one in 2010. A United Nations reconnaissance mission to the affected areas found "less significant damages than initially expected," the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said Sunday." https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/15/world/haiti-earthquake-news-sunday/index.html

Comments: Heads up: area is in the middle of the hurricane season. Affirming forecast.
CNN, 08/15/21, 'Death toll from 7.2-magnitude earthquake in Haiti rises to over 1,200 people': https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/15/world/haiti-earthquake-news-sunday/index.html
CNN, 08/15/21, 'Fred regains tropical storm status en route to Florida as Haiti braces for Grace': https://www.cnn.com/2021/08/15/weather/grace-fred-storms-sunday/index.html
NOAA, 05/20/21, 'NOAA predicts another active Atlantic hurricane season': https://www.noaa.gov/news-release/noaa-predicts-another-active-atlantic-hurricane-season
It is important and likely for the orderly transition of power, but the earthquake has complicated matters, reducing access and creating a more urgent crisis to address than elections.

- 8 
Maybe the currently planned for 26 septembre will "more" (1) be postpone. it's a major earthquake.
https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/magnitude-7-quake-strikes-western-haiti-usgs-2021-08-14/
(has @probahilliby mention to me, it was already postponed)
A few percent down because of the earthquake like @probahilliby @cdob63 @bh4eh @jayb

This morning's earthquake is likely to hold things up some more, so I'm moving down some.  Haiti just can't catch a break.  (Assuming that an election would be considered a break in Haiti; opinion is not unanimous on this.)
Lots happening with this one. 7.2 (or greater) earthquake earlier today is not likely to help the process of elections of any kind; https://bit.ly/3sfutNr

Awaiting more information but today's serious Haiti earthquake with "widespread damage + high casualties" could be something of a 'black swan'-type event for this question.  No significant change to forecast pending more info. https://www.cnn.com/world/live-news/haiti-earthquake-08-14-21/index.html, https://news.yahoo.com/major-earthquake-hits-southern-western-135037626.html
Adjusted & awaiting clarification as per @timothy_chan - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1320961

Decrease due to a magnitude 7.2 earthquake in the region. I could see the potential that damage and fatalities are so high that recovery becomes a more urgent matter than holding an election. But I'm not too sure. Coincidentally or not, my forecast, aligns with the magnitude of the earthquake. Others' input is highly welcome at this point. @jayb
@timothy_chan

There were 7 presidential elections since 1990 and it looks like only the one from 2010-2011 had a second round of elections. (Numbers from Wikipedia)
Year	Second round of elections? (0 = False, 1 = True)	Who won and how much
1990	0	Aristide, 67.5%
1995	0	Preval, 82.2%
2000	0	Aristide, 91.7%
2006	0	Preval, 51.1%
2010-11	1	Martelly, 67.6%
2015	0	Annulled
2016	0	Moise, 55.6%

@bh4eh makes a good point regarding a possible second round of elections. I asked for a clarification about whether an inconclusive first round of elections held before 1 January 2022 would count towards an affirmative resolution. Based on the question description I don't think that's the intention, so I'll lower my probability estimate at least until I get a response. Good idea to look at the base rate for second elections being held. Will try to do that later.

There appears to be some confusion about the recently released documents scheduling elections on Nov 7, 2021 (https://reut.rs/3sa107k). Two sources, https://bit.ly/3ACCsXL & https://bit.ly/2Uasn4C, indicate that; "According to the new electoral calendar, the second round of presidential and legislative elections will be on January 23, 2022 at the same time as municipal and local elections, which have also been delayed for years." Thus, IMO, 'a presidential election' will not be completed before 1 January 2022 as per this question.
@MCowley

"Haiti will hold presidential elections last scheduled for September on November 7, officials said Wednesday, with the assassination of president Jovenel Moise still shrouded in mystery." https://www.france24.com/en/americas/20210812-haiti-postpones-election-date-to-replace-assassinated-president "PORT-AU-PRINCE, Aug 11 (Reuters) - Haiti's elections have been postponed to Nov. 7, according to local media on Wednesday, following the killing last month of President Jovenel Moise, which plunged the country into political turmoil. Documents apparently issued by the government that were circulated on social media on Wednesday disclosed the postponement of the presidential and legislative elections, as well as a constitutional referendum, which had previously been scheduled for Sept. 26. Reuters could not independently verify the authenticity of the documents. Haiti's electoral council did not immediately reply to requests for comment." https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/haiti-elections-replace-slain-president-postponed-nov-7-media-2021-08-12/

Comments: Investigation stalled. Fear and uncertainty still rule. I just don't see the UN jumping on this after 15 years trying to stabilize the country; 2004-2019 (MINUSTAH followed by MINUJUSTH). Affirming forecast.
Al-Jazeera, 08/07/21, 'Haiti: Many questions, few answers one month after Moise killing': https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/7/haiti-many-questions-few-answers-one-month-after-moise-killing, 
Clips from the article:
'On Thursday, the Haitian government requested help from the United Nations to conduct an international investigation, saying that Haiti considered the attack an international crime due to the alleged role of foreigners in planning, financing and carrying it out.
“I hope that the UN is going to respond favourably because that’s the least that the UN can do for Haiti and the Caribbean,” Lamothe said, “remembering that Haiti is the first Black republic in the world and we deserve all the international cooperation to find out who killed the president.”
Meanwhile, the Haitian justice system has struggled to find a judge willing to probe the killing.
“It is a sensitive, political dossier. Before agreeing to investigate it, a judge thinks about his own safety and that of his family,” one judge told the AFP news agency on condition of anonymity this week. “For this reason, investigating magistrates are not too enthusiastic about accepting it.”
Several magistrates have told the dean of the Court of First Instance in Port-au-Prince that they are not interested in working on the assassination.
Senior magistrate Bernard Saint-Vil said he would announce on Thursday the name of the investigating magistrate chosen to take on the case, but in the end, he could not because no judge wanted the job.' 'Amid a lack of clarity and competing claims over who would take control after Moise’s killing, Haiti last month appointed a new interim prime minister, Ariel Henry. Henry has promised to hold elections “as quickly as possible” to get the country out of its political crisis.
But leading Haitian civil society leaders have questioned whether holding a vote later this year – a key demand from the UN and the United States, among other international actors – is possible amid the widespread insecurity.'
Another statement of determination (to hold elections): https://www.voanews.com/americas/haiti-electoral-council-chief-vows-hold-elections-despite-setbacks

Excerpts from a 7/27/21 Washington Post opinion article: "There is no way for Haiti to pull itself out of the current morass without elections that would certify and legitimize a new government and legislature. That requires at least a short-term international intervention....Boots on the ground will be necessary." https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2021/07/27/haiti-needs-elections-outside-forces-make-them-safe/

I fail to understand why, with an assassinated President, anyone would want to delay an election. Although, anything could happen, so perhaps not 100%, especially since it may be some time before proper order etc is restored and preparation for the elections can take place.

I'm pretty dumb on this subject but if our leader was assassinated months before an election, would that mean we are not to have the election because of some outlaw bandits with murderous intent? The members of government perhaps feel an obligation to elect a new leader—and Haiti's request for American troops tell me they still have regard for democracy on its soil. Yes, the assassination of its leader is such a debilitating event and puts Haiti in such a dire situation, but that dire frame shouldn't necessarily be translated to the context of this question. How often is Haiti without a president? Typically how long are vacancy periods? It seems that all previous assassinated presidents of Haiti were replaced by someone who took the helm not long after assassination and stayed in power for a few years each, minimum.
The country is in chaos. There needs to be time for campaigning.
No, there are no legislative tools to do that, and emergency case can lead to Coup or transitional period.
A new prime minister has just sworn in (yesterday) and it is expected that there is a transition period that will go into mid 2022, at least, before the next elections are held.
Revised position on more comprehensive review this morning.

As a general rule (often a major-general rule), a person or party possessing a useful mix of formal authority, strongarm support, and shameless chutzpah will not conduct elections until it is absolutely necessary.  It becomes necessary when one or more of those three ingredients dwindle sufficiently.   You, Gentle Reader, will have noticed the utter lack of precision about how much of what is useful or sufficient.  If I knew, I'd tell you, but alas there is no formula for this.  Sorry.

Comments: No US or French troops, but Haitian people deeply suspicious and opposed to recent accommodation. Considering Joseph move as maneuvering, not sincere. Don't forget Aristide. Would not be surprised if Ms Moise announces her candidacy to complete husband's term. 
Washington Post, 07/19/21, 'Haiti’s acting prime minister Claude Joseph says he will step down amid leadership dispute': https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/07/19/haiti-claude-joseph-ariel-henry/
France 24, 07/16/21, 'France says military intervention in Haiti 'not on agenda': https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210716-france-says-military-intervention-in-haiti-not-on-agenda

Beginning with a higher forecast for the moment until it's more clear to me that scheduled Sept. 26,2021 general elections will not be held. Article excerpt: "On 8 July, interim prime minister Claude Joseph’s office announced that despite the assassination, the legislative elections would still be held on the date set by the Provisional Electoral Council and that members of the opposition would be included in election timetable talks..." Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Haitian_general_election 7/19/21: Noting that Claude Joseph is apparently no longer Haiti's acting prime minister: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/19/world/americas/claude-joseph-haiti-stepping-down.html Another article excerpt: "...Elections have been planned for September, but many civil society groups in Haiti worry that holding them would only sharpen the political crisis. They question whether it would even be feasible to hold legitimate elections given how weak the nation’s institutions have become, and some civil society leaders were expected to meet Saturday [7/17/21] to try to devise a new path forward." https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/07/10/world/jovenel-moise-assassinated/the-assassination-of-moise-stirs-a-battle-for-control-in-public-and-behind-the-scenes Sept. 26 is near the peak of Atlantic hurricane season, as others have pointed out

The issue here is to ask who is in control in Haiti after the assassination of the incumbent. The Parliament has not been functioning for the last 18 months having been ruled by decree by Moise and only ten sitting Senators, no deputies and the President of Haiti’s court died of Covid in June. The constitution is moribund.
The choice of Prime Minister, selected by the President, has to be ratified by both Houses of the Legislature and that is not functioning.
With no visible functioning arm of Government and a constitution in a state of flux, it will take considerable time and possible international assistance/intervention (perhaps the US)  to formulate and organise an electoral process to allow for an election.
https://theconversation.com/whos-running-haiti-after-presidents-assassination-5-questions-answered-164287  https://www.un.org/press/en/2021/sc14554.doc.htm  https://www.voanews.com/americas/haiti-civil-society-commission-wants-select-new-president  https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210710-who-will-lead-haiti-after-president-s-killing  https://theconversation.com/after-its-president-was-assassinated-haiti-needs-international-help-more-than-ever-164285

"Moise's inauguration was delayed over allegations of voter fraud during the 2015 election, which led to a presidential runoff that was postponed twice over what authorities called threats and 'security concerns.' " https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/07/americas/haiti-explainer-jovenel-moise-assassination-cmd-intl/index.html “This is creating a perfect storm because the population has lowered its guard, the infrastructure of COVID-19 beds has been reduced, the security situation could deteriorate even further and hurricane season has started,” read a statement by the Pan American Health Organization, sent by email Wednesday. https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/07/08/haiti-health-crisis/ Considering they have virtually no vaccinations and Covid has been readily used to delay numerous events, plus the long track record of delays, it's not looking promising. Pack on hurricanes and gang violence and I'll be impressed if they pull an election off. I'll start a bit higher than expecting for a bit of optimism and go from there.

Elections have previously been postponed stating that they needed more time to deal with the pandemic. Still haven't dealt with it amidst increasing chaos. Considering the murder of Moise, not sure the referendum he sponsored is timely but I don't understand the politics behind it.

Comments: Nope.
Marine Times, 07/16/21, 'Marines headed to protect embassy in Haiti, but no troops to stabilize nation, says Biden': https://www.marinecorpstimes.com/news/pentagon-congress/2021/07/16/marines-headed-to-protect-embassy-in-haiti-but-no-troops-to-stabilize-nation-says-biden/
Clips from Times article:
'He also said Biden’s comment that sending U.S. troops was “not on the agenda” still leaves the option open.
“This is not a closed door. The evolution of the situation will determine the outcome,” Pierre said. “In the meantime, the government is doing everything we can to stabilize the country, return to a normal environment and organize elections while trying to come to a political agreement with most political parties.”
The Marines were part of the Marine Security Guard Security Augmentation Unit, sent to Port-Au-Prince “out of an abundance of caution,” a State Department spokesperson told Marine Corps Times on Friday.
The unit was created after the 2012 attack U.S. facilities in Benghazi, Libya, that resulted in the death of four Americans including the U.S. Ambassador to Libya J. Christopher Stevens.' Comments: See Aristide's return adding to the turmoil.
Yahoo News, 07/16/21, 'Hundreds greet Aristide on return to troubled Haiti': https://news.yahoo.com/official-aristide-return-haiti-fully-125946360.html

Haiti has been in turmoil for so long, and now with the recent assassination of the president, together with soaring Covid cases, on top of all of its other difficulties, Haiti faces even more difficult times ahead. I think a power struggle between Prime Minister Joseph and Dr. Henry is likely to continue until one of them is able to take and/or bargain for nearly all power for himself. The governing structure of the country is in such disarray that I think elections are unlikely before January 1, 2022. Whoever is in power might also claim that greater stability is needed before elections could be held. I think there might eventually be elections at some point in the next 1 to 3 years, but I think they will only happen when either PM Joseph or Dr. Henry (or some third person who manages to insert himself or herself into the power struggle) feels either forced to hold them or assured of victory.
https://theconversation.com/whos-running-haiti-after-presidents-assassination-5-questions-answered-164287 Update 7/19: "the country's acting Prime Minister Claude Joseph has agreed to step down and hand power to his rival Ariel Henry, according to a top government official." "According to Pierre, the elections minister, elections are likely to be held 120 days after Henry is sworn in as prime minister." So now the time table is bumped to at least mid-November.
https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/19/americas/haiti-acting-pm-claude-joseph-to-step-down-intl/index.html
Strongly doubt it. The country is in turmoil and they barely have a functioning Senate, and no Chief Justice.
